Arts Reviews

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Owen Jones: The Politics Of Hope

By James Bithell

Guardian columnist and author shares ideas with a welcome vigor to a full house at The Assembly Rooms

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Institute

By James Bithell

Gecko's surreal production impresses Amy Wong thanks to its imaginative staging and flawless choreography

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: The Solid Life of Sugar Water

Incisive writing and strong performances make Jack Thorne's play about loss, hurt and rediscovery a Fringe highlight for Amy Wong

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Antiwords

Spitfire give a new beauty to the big-headed in this perceptive play set in an era of communist rule

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Paul Foot

The raconteur and idiosyncratic stand-up comedian has a habit of getting sidetracked which can work to his advantage. Adam Koper reviews

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Charolais

By James Bithell

Noni Stapleton deserves a bigger, better loved production for her superb turn as a farmhand competing with a prize cow for the affections of the farmer

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Tonight with Donny Stixx

Feverish theatre from a one-man cast explores the dark past of a deluded man in a brutally impressive production

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: The Red Chair

By James Bithell

This one woman drama starts as a poetically impressive piece of experimental theatre, but descends all too soon into freeform chaos

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: NewsRevue

The lauded sketch troupe draw crowds, delivering faultless topical mockery and damaging a few egos along the way. Tess Pullen reviews

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Sarah Callaghan: Elephant

Funny-woman finalist defines and defies her personal space to make for a confident Fringe debut

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: The Outsider

By James Bithell

A surreal, charismatic display of technological genius helps this one man concept project overcome some lumpiness

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Ian Smith: Whereabouts

Yorkshire-boy and laid-back funnyman puts his audience at ease with a witty, if orthodox, set. Liam Mullally reviews

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: John Lloyd: Emperor of the Prawns

By James Bithell

The creator of QI steps up for stand-up, and reveals a huge amount of his knowledge to great effect. Liam Mullally reviews

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Jena Friedman: American C*nt

Liam Mullally applauds the comedian's attempts to traverse complex issues even if it does cost the show a few jokes

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Jess Robinson

Comedy with flair and vocal perfection comes courtesy of singer and impersonator, Jess Robinson and her co-star, Kirsty Newton

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Stewart Lee: A Room with a Stew

The embittered comedian sets out to criticise his audience but reviewer Liam Mullally sees the funny side

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: TES

Steve Larkin's modern retelling of Tess of the D'Urbervilles fails to inspire reviewer Amy Wong

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Abigoliah Schamaun: Post-Coital Confessions

With a welcoming and disarming honesty, the American comedian sets out to shock her prudish British audience, with some success. Tess Pullen reviews

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Alex Williamson: That Guy from the Internet

By James Bithell

Bogan Aussie steps into the limelight with fresh stand-up that follows a basic model but shows that he might have more to offer

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Current Location

By James Bithell

Non-action is questioned in a challenging play about the difficulty of addressing environmental issues, backed-up by an unsettling soundtrack. Liam Mullally reviews

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Circa: Close up

Daring acrobatics from fringe favourites Circa, keep the audience on tenterhooks but a broken fourth wall damages the effect. Tess Pullen reviews

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Hal Cruttenden

By James Bithell

York alumnus and seasoned comic charms the audience with impeccable Fringe wit in his latest show. Amy Bishop reviews

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Party

By James Bithell

A young cast hold together an energetic production of Tom Basden's political student satire

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Trainspotting

From the streets of Leith to cult-sensation at the hands of Danny Boyle, the novel Trainspotting hit big. This unflinching production follows suit

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Ashes Afar

The multi-national Vanner Collective, weave a tale of modern love in the age of immigration for their contemplative play which doesn't always hit home

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Lily Bevan: Pheasant Plucker

By James Bithell

Sketch comic, Lily Bevan whips up an expansive entourage of characters and forms an unusual bond with her audience in the process. Liam Mullally reviews

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Dane Baptiste

By James Bithell

Comic and social commentator's second appearance at the Fringe has all the elements of a top class show but doesn't consistently come together

Review: McEwan's Women

A well-handled rendition of 7 McEwan works portrays the power of his female characters. Holly Woolnough reviews

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Every Brilliant Thing

By James Bithell

Jonny Donahoe gets a deserved standing ovation in this one man play about finding joy in the darkest places

Edinburgh Fringe 2015 Review: Spillikin: A Love Story

Pipeline Theatre's play about the memories of an Alzheimer's sufferer left with a robot companion astounds reviewer Amy Wong
